articles.headline: 5 Options for Congress to Cut Taxes
articles.snippet: Five compromises worth considering as Congress debates the Bush tax cuts, which expire on Dec. 31.
articles.abstract: Five compromises worth considering as Congress debates the Bush tax cuts, which expire on Dec. 31.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush tax cuts expire in 58 days.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Initial Crew Moving On
articles.snippet: With stock options worth as much as $1.8 billion, a number of Facebook’s early employees are giving up their stable jobs to do what they say they like best: start companies.
articles.abstract: With stock options worth as much as $1.8 billion, a number of Facebook’s early employees are giving up their stable jobs to do what they say they like best: start companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook, the most successful start-up of the last decade, is only six years old, and an initial public offering is still a way off.

articles.headline: Washington Played a Big Part in G.M. Turnaround
articles.snippet: The Obama administration distanced itself from day-to-day management of G.M. but played an important role in decisions on leadership and strategy.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration distanced itself from day-to-day management of G.M. but played an important role in decisions on leadership and strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  When executives from General Motors begin pitching its public stock offering to investors this week, they will extol the company’s financial turnaround, its snazzy new car lineup led by the plug-in Chevrolet Volt, and its growing operations in China and other international markets.

articles.headline: Many Voters Find Little Comfort on Ballot
articles.snippet: At the polls, a mood of grim resignation meant voting in ways that seemed out of the question two years ago.
articles.abstract: At the polls, a mood of grim resignation meant voting in ways that seemed out of the question two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Want to know what’s wrong with this country? Just ask everyone.

articles.headline: Cotton Clothing Price Tags to Rise
articles.snippet: Chinese and American demand is up, but the crop was hurt by flooding in Pakistan and bad weather in China and India.
articles.abstract: Chinese and American demand is up, but the crop was hurt by flooding in Pakistan and bad weather in China and India.
articles.lead_paragraph: Synthetic linings. Smaller buttons. Less Italian fabric. And yes, even more polyester. Unusually high cotton prices have apparel makers scrambling to keep down costs, but consumers be warned: cotton clothing will be getting more expensive.

articles.headline: Tea Party Comes to Power on an Unclear Mandate
articles.snippet: The movement has a stated distaste for the compromises of legislating and a wary relationship with G.O.P. leaders.
articles.abstract: The movement has a stated distaste for the compromises of legislating and a wary relationship with G.O.P. leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tea Party movement set the agenda in its first midterms, its energy propelling the Republican sweep in the House and capturing the mood of a significant chunk of the electorate, with a remarkable 4 in 10 voters in exit polls expressing support for the movement.

articles.headline: In Republican Victories, Tide Turns Starkly
articles.snippet: The apostle of change became its target, engulfed by the same discontent that vaulted him to the White House.
articles.abstract: The apostle of change became its target, engulfed by the same discontent that vaulted him to the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Somewhere along the way, the apostle of change became its target, engulfed by the same currents that swept him to the White House two years ago. Now, President Obama must find a way to recalibrate with nothing less than his presidency on the line.

articles.headline: Harry Reid Keeps His Seat as Democrats Hold Senate
articles.snippet: The Senate majority leader from Nevada was a top target of national Republicans and Tea Party activists, who saw a chance for an upset win that would ring with historical resonance.
articles.abstract: The Senate majority leader from Nevada was a top target of national Republicans and Tea Party activists, who saw a chance for an upset win that would ring with historical resonance.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader and a symbol of the Democratic establishment, fought back a fierce challenge from Sharron Angle to win re-election on Tuesday in a contest that offered a stark test of the Tea Party against one of the most effective political operations in the nation.

articles.headline: Deep Rifts Divide Obama and Republicans
articles.snippet: A day after Democrats got what the president called a “shellacking,” both parties explored the reshaped political terrain.
articles.abstract: A day after Democrats got what the president called a “shellacking,” both parties explored the reshaped political terrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and newly empowered Republican leaders professed a desire Wednesday to work together but yielded little ground on deep policy differences, foreshadowing the profound challenge of turning around a flagging economy under a divided government.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Carl Hulse
